messages.content: Hi (:leaf) I’m <PERSON>. You’re safe here to share anything, no judgment. How have you been feeling lately?
I feel like I can't go on. Sometimes I think it would be better if I wasn't here (:sad).
I hear you. That sounds incredibly heavy. You don't have to face this alone. Reaching out is already a brave step. Are you safe right now, or do you feel in immediate danger?
I’m at my home in <LOCATION>. I have some pills, but I haven’t taken any yet.
Thank you for sharing that. Let’s focus on your safety first. Can you put the pills somewhere out of reach and call a friend or family member right now?
I don’t want to bother anyone. My friend <PERSON> always says I’m overreacting (:sad)
You are not overreacting. Your feelings are real and valid. Sometimes friends don’t know how to respond, but your life matters and deserves support.
I don't know. I feel so alone.

You’re not alone, even if it feels that way. Would you consider calling a trained crisis line? In <LOCATION>, you can reach Teléfono de la Esperanza: <PHONE_NUMBER> or visit <URL>. They are available 24/7.
I don't want to call anyone. Talking online is easier.
That's okay. Let's keep talking here while you consider reaching someone. Can you tell me what's been weighing on you the most lately?
I failed my exams again. My parents shouted at me and said I'll never succeed.
That sounds very painful. Academic pressure and harsh criticism can make things feel unbearable. But failing an exam doesn’t define your worth. You’re more than grades.
But I feel worthless. My cousin <PERSON> always does better than me and my boyfriend said I’m lazy…
It's understandable that these words hurt. Comparisons can intensify self-criticism. You deserve compassion and patience, especially from yourself.
I even wrote a message to my old therapist yesterday, but she didn't reply yet.
Waiting for a reply can feel discouraging, but reaching out was a brave step. You’re showing self-awareness and care for yourself.
I also keep thinking about how easy it would be to just end it.
Thank you for being honest. Those thoughts are serious, and I want you to stay safe. Can you stay with someone you trust right now, even if it’s just a family member in the same house?
Maybe. My brother <PERSON> is home. He doesn’t know how bad I feel.
Could you tell him something simple like, "I need someone to be with me right now"? You don’t have to explain everything yet. Just presence can help you feel safer.
I can try. I just feel hopeless.

Hopelessness can feel heavy, but it can pass with support. While you reach out to <PERSON>, I strongly encourage calling a crisis line too. They are trained to listen and help you stay safe right now.
Ok, maybe I will. It's just hard.
Absolutely, it’s hard. But you’re taking steps—reaching out here, considering calling someone, and thinking about safety. That’s strength.
Thanks <PERSON>. I feel a tiny bit lighter just talking.
I'm glad (:relieved). Remember, these thoughts do not define you, and you deserve care and support. Please reach out to a trained professional now if you can. You're not alone.
I'll try to call the Teléfono de la Esperanza now.
Perfect (:star) that’s a very brave step. Stay close to your brother <PERSON> while you do. You deserve help and safety.
